articles.title: EDS 411AB: MEDS Capstone
articles.contents:
Image: a single green plant seedling in red soil. Photo by David von Diemar on Unsplash



Course description
The goal of EDS 411A is to facilitate student learning, work and progress on their MEDS Capstone project through lessons, activities, supervised and unsupervised project work, and peer review and feedback. Additionally, EDS 411A provides opportunities for professional and career development (e.g. presentation skills, writing and editing, client relations, team science, panel discussions, and conflict resolution).
Throughout the course, students will build on skills they have learned in prior MEDS courses to implement them in a real-world data science project, including:
Prepare professional documentation for a data science project through the Design and Implementation Plan, and Technical Documentation
Practice project management and reproducible workflows using tools and strategies learned in MEDS courses, establishing clear expectations for group roles and participation, and with frequent updates within and across groups
Continue to build real-world skills for data science projects through continued collaborative work in git, data analyses and statistics, data visualization and communication, and more
Implement professional skills for data science careers including code and documentation peer review, team and client relations, scheduling and organizing tools & strategies, and conflict resolution & communication

articles.title: Week 1: Hello, (Capstone) world!
articles.contents:
Week 1 Materials
Week 1 Slides
Week 1 Goals:
EDS 411AB course introduction
What are we doing here?
What is the time expectation?
How will I be evaluated?
How do we get help?

Tell us about your project! 2-minute flash talks
Write a short paragraph on your project for the Bren website
Finance team visit - how to use your Capstone funds
Decide on a project alias
Define team roles
1:00pm - 1:30pm: EDS 411AB Course Intro
EDS 411A Course Intro Slides
1:30pm - 2:15pm: Project Flash Talks
Spend 15 minutes creating then practicing a 2 to 3 minute, 4 slide presentation on your project. The 4 slides should be (1) Cover slide, (2) Background, (3) Project motivation (or problem / knowledge gap), (4) Project objective(s). Your group can decide how you break up the presentation - 2 presenters minimum.
Break: 2:15pm - 2:30pm PST
2:30pm - 3:00pm: Write a summary for the Bren website
Each MEDS Capstone project will be featured on the Bren website. Spend ~10 minutes browsing some MESM project summaries to get an idea of what is expected. Then, start drafting your paragraph for the website in the shared document.
Continue to work on your summary after 411A this week. Add a finalized version of your summary to this shared google doc by Monday 1/11 at 5pm. We will then share that document with Melissa Van De Werfhorst (Bren Communications Director) to post your summaries to the Bren website.
Finance - using your group money (3:00pm - 3:30pm)
Members of the Bren finance team will join via Zoom to go over important information about using your Capstone budget & how to use it.
Break: 3:30pm - 3:45pm
3:45pm - 4:00pm: Team alias!
Your team alias - a short, memorable abbreviated name for your project - serves multiple professional purposes, including:
The directory name on Taylor
Your group’s email prefix
Use in MEDS Capstone communication with faculty and staff
Spend 15 minutes brainstorming group aliases. Keep in mind that this will likely be part of a file path, so using good practices for naming things is in your best interest. Some examples of team aliases from previous Bren MESM projects are:
nadatrace (evaluated opportunities for Nada Groceries to minimize waste)
worthwhale (economic valuation of whale watching & marine planning in Dominica)
maricultura (assessed Brazil’s aquaculture potential)
justhealth (investigated relationships between air quality and diabetes risk in California)
Once you have decided on your team alias, send it to Brad & Kat so they can set up your Taylor directory and group email address.
4:00 - 5:00pm - Define team roles and report back
All teams are required to have a project manager (PM) and communication manager (CM). Other roles should be decided based on project-specific needs and expectations. Discuss with your team - in addition to the PM and CM, what do you think are the most important roles for the success of the project?
Add your proposed roles to this shared doc by the end of the day. You should discuss the proposed roles with your faculty advisor, and make updates to the Googlesheet to finalize your project roles by Friday, January 11th.
What you should do before next week:
All members should read through the MEDS Capstone Guidelines
Prepare a first draft of the Team Management Plan section of your Design & Implementation Plan (and feel free to work on other sections!)
Let Brad & Kat know your team alias ASAP (so they can create your Taylor directory & email)
Finalize your summary paragraph for the Bren website, add to this shared doc by 5pm on Monday 1/11
Make sure your project roles are updated on the shared Googlesheet

articles.title: Week 2: Working with clients, and starting solution design
articles.contents:
Week 2 Materials
Week 2 Slides
Week 2 Goals:
Address questions on Team Management Plan
Group sharing: what worked & didn’t from Week 1?
Peer review: Team Management Plan
Tips for working with clients on a data science project
Introducing the Solution Design
Sketching out & presenting a Solution Design schematic
Today’s timeline:
1:00 - 1:30 - Reminders, Meeting Tips, Questions & “What worked?”
1:30 - 2:15 - Team management plan peer review
2:15 - 2:30 - Break
2:30 - 3:00 - Working with a client - a few big tips
3:00 - 3:15 - Introducing the Solution Design section
3:15 - 3:45 - Sketchy Solution Design
3:45 - 4:00 - Break
4:00 - 4:30 - Present your sketch (3 minutes each group)
4:30 - 4:45 - Clarify questions you have for Solution Design
4:50 - 5:00 - Designated team time
What you should do before next week:
Make your list of Products and Deliverables (section e of D&I Plan)
Drafted timeline for your work (unrelated to Bren deliverables - this should be specifically for your data science product work). Review timeline with advisor / client this week or next.
Skeleton draft of Solution Design, with a schematic to share in 411A next week. The point is to clarify what you don’t know and still need. Schematics are encouraged in your D&I plan, so this could / should end up being a final figure in your submitted document.
Based on your Team Management Plan, create your repo (most likely) or whatever tool you’re using for project accountability & progress tracking. Add action items for each person, each week (i.e. each person should have a “to-do” list). Share with both faculty advisors.

articles.title: Week 3: Problems, mishaps & blameless postmortems
articles.contents:
Week 3 Materials
Week 3 Slides
Week 3 Goals:
Address questions on Solution Design
Share a “Weekly Win”
Peer review & sharing: Solution Design
“State of your data” blitz
Introduction to the blameless postmortem
Clarifying the problem / gap that your project addresses
Today’s timeline:
1:00 - 1:30 - Reminders, questions & share some wins / ideas
1:30 - 2:00 - Solution design group sharing & questions / gaps clarified
2:00 - 2:10 - Break
2:10 - 2:25 - Group time (flash talk prep)
2:25 - 3:00 - Flash talks (solution design overview)
3:00 - 3:20 - “State of your data” blitz
3:20 - 3:30 - Break
3:30 - 4:00 - Mishaps & blameless postmortems (mini-lecture / discussion)
4:00 - 4:15 - What’s your problem? (research storytelling mini-lecture)
4:15 - 4:45 - From background to specific problem / gap - directed work
4:45 - 5:00 - Wrap up & group time
What you should do before next week:
Draft Problem Statement and Objectives section of Design & Implementation Plan
Continue work on Solution Design section (full draft expected, or placeholders where gaps exist)
Next week be prepared to present:
A 3 minute flash talk on Timeline & Milestones (2 presenters minimum)
A 3 - 4 minute presentation (2 presenters minimum) with the following:
Cover slide (1 slide)
Background (1 - 2 slides)
Problem / gap (1 slide)
Objectives (1 slide)

articles.title: Week 4: Faculty reviews, responding to questions, postmortems, and flash talks
articles.contents:
Week 4 Materials
Week 4 Slides
Week 4 Goals:
Flash talks: timelines & milestones, background & objectives
Faculty Review: what to expect, logistics, overview
Responding to questions
Postmortems
Today’s timeline:
1:00 - 1:20 - Reminders, questions & share some wins / ideas
1:20 - 1:45 - “State of your data” discussion (group sharing)
1:45 - 2:45 - Flash talks: Background, problem, objectives
2:45 - 3:00 - Break
3:00 - 3:45 - Faculty Reviews Part 1: logistics, content, questions
3:45 - 4:00 - Break
4:00 - 4:30 - Flash talks: Timelines & milestones
4:30 - 4:50 - Productive postmortems
4:50 - 5:00 - Group time
What you should do before next week:
Draft Documentation Plan section of Design & Implementation Plan
Continue editing and weaving drafted sections of D&I Plan
Read this short post on different types of software testing, and this one on data quality, to understand some different testing and data quality flavors (we’ll discuss more next week)
Brainstorm different ways you are concerned your product and/or data could break / fail. Prepare a 2-slide flash talk (3 minutes, 2 presenters) to share expected breaks. This will motivate group discussions & feedback on product testing.

articles.title: Week 5: Testing and Faculty Reviews Part 2
articles.contents:
Week 5 Materials
Week 5 Slides
Week 5 Goals:
Lessons: flavors of testing
Part 2 of Capstone Faculty Review Information
Directed work: testing brainstorm and peer feedback
Practice presenting a graph
Today’s timeline:
1:00 - 1:10 - Intro, questions, wins
1:10 - 1:30 - How to present a data visualization
1:30 - 1:50 - Mini-lecture - Testing
1:50 - 2:20 - Breaking things flash talks
2:20 - 2:35 - Break
2:35 - 4:00 - Group discussions, peer feedback & work: Testing plan
4:00 - 4:15 - Break
4:15 - 4:45 - Capstone Faculty Reviews: Part 2
4:45 - 5:00 - Group time
What you should do before next week:
Draft Testing Plan section of Design & Implementation Plan
Continue editing and weaving drafted sections of D&I Plan
Have a full draft of your Design & Implementation plan ready to share with another group to get feedback
Prepare a skeleton slide deck for your faculty review presentation (like an outline, but with the sections as slide headers). Populate with stuff you have already.
Resources for testing
Jeff Perkel (2022) How to fix your scientific coding errors. Nature Technology Feature.
DataONE Best Practices - Data Assurance
Google Testing and Debugging in ML
Fay et al. Engineering Production-Grade Shiny Apps Ch. 11 - Build yourself a safety net
Taschuk and Wilson (2017) Ten simple rules for making research software more robust. PLOS Comp Bio.

articles.contents:
Week 6 Materials
Week 6 Slides
Week 6 Goals:
Quick tips: Slide design

Allison rotating (25 min / group)

articles.title: Week 7: Responding to questions, practice presentations
articles.contents:
Week 7 Materials
Week 7 Slides
Week 7 Goals:
Tips for responding to questions
Identify question bins and start brainstorming
Practice presentations and feedback for Faculty Reviews
Discuss strategies for delegating tasks (efficient coworking)
Today’s timeline:
1:00 - 1:15 - Intro, questions, reminders
1:15 - 1:45 - Efficient coworking discussion
1:45 - 2:15 - Mini-lecture - Question bins
2:15 - 2:30 - Break
2:30 - 3:00 - Identify your question bins, brainstorm 2 - 3 questions per bin
3:00 - 5:00 - Practice presentations and feedback
What you should do before next week for 411A:
Edit your Design & Implementation Plan once feedback received
Iterate on your presentation (and practice giving it)
Continue adding to your question bins
